sentence: Disinflation, not deflation, could be the likely scenario facing the U.S. economy.
Disinflation is a period of slowing price increases.
Deflation is a prolonged period of falling prices.
Though deflation has been getting a lot of press, most economists are assigning a low probability to it actually occurring.
What they are assigning a high probability to is the Federal Reserve keeping interest rates unchanged.
A new poll by Reuters shows a consensus opinion that the first rate hike will not occur until at least mid-2011.
This represents a reversal from economists who, until fairly recently, were calling for a rate hike to occur at some point this year.
The reason why chatter about deflation is getting louder is because the economic recovery has been so painfully slow.
The Federal Open Market Committee summed up the disappointment of many when it opined on Tuesday, "The pace of economic recovery is likely more modest in the near term than had been anticipated."
Assuming the Fed is right, companies will continue to have problems exerting pricing power, meaning they won't be able to raise prices without customer resistance or lost sales.
Rather, companies will have to look to either new product introductions or acquisitions to drive revenues higher.
Given past cutting measures, maintaining strong earnings growth could prove difficult for those companies unable to find a way to increase sales.
Combined, this means qualitative analysis (looking at the factors that are influencing the numbers) will take on an added importance.
The cost of capital should remain at comparatively low levels for many companies.
This is a double-edged sword.
On the one hand, it lowers interest costs, which increases earnings and cash flow.
On the other, it reduces the risk premium applied to future cash flows, which, in turn, lowers the price targets calculated by commonly used valuation models.
In simpler terms, a brokerage analyst needs to explain why the company will generate more cash over the next few years than he previously forecast to justify maintaining his price target.
I should really describe the cost of capital as a triple-edged sword, because it also creates increased reinvestment risk for bond investors.
As older bonds with higher yields mature, investors will have to either accept lower yields from newer bonds or be willing to buy bonds with higher levels of credit risk and/or longer maturities.
The one piece of good news is that in a low inflation environment existing bonds should hold their value, assuming credit risks don't change.
(Obviously, if the economic environment or sentiment changes, bond prices will change as well.)
How commodities will perform is less clear.
Slow growth in demand from the U.S. will be a drag on price appreciation for industrial metals, oil, natural gas and coal.
Offsetting this could be changes in global demand and currency fluctuations.
Supply issues are also a factor, as has been the case with wheat, which has rallied since early July.
In writing this week's commentary, I looked to see the last time the U.S. experienced low inflation and slow economic growth.

What I found, unsurprisingly, is that low inflation and slow economic growth are not new to the U.S. During the period of 1956 to 1961, economic growth averaged 2.5% per year and inflation averaged 1.9% per year.
(According to the National Bureau of Economic Research ((NBER)), the U.S. economy experienced two recessions over this period.
The first occurred between August 1957 and April 1958, and the second occurred between April 1960 and February 1961.)
Though I wouldn't say that we are seeing history repeat itself-the global economy is much different now-the data does show that there are other low inflation scenarios besides Japan.
What is even more interesting was the performance of the S&P 500, which rewarded investors for maintaining an allocation to equities.
The table below shows the data.
Keep in mind that I am not saying this is what will happen, but rather simply showing there is precedent for sticking with stocks in this type of economic scenario.
Sources: National Bureau of Economic Research, Bureau of Labor Statistics, Leonard N. Stern School of Business.
A large number of retailers will report earnings this week, including Lowe's (( LOW ) - Monday), Home Depot (( HD ) - Tuesday), Wal-Mart ([[WMT]] - Tuesday) and Target ([[TGT]] - Wednesday).
A total of 25 S&P 500 members are currently scheduled to announce second-quarter results, including Dow components HD, WMT and Hewlett-Packard ([[HPQ]] - Thursday).
The August National Association of Home Builders' ((NAHB)) housing index and the New York Fed's Empire State manufacturing survey will be published on Monday.
Tuesday features July housing starts, the July Producer Price Index ((PPI)), and July industrial production and capacity utilization.
The Conference Board's July leading indicator index and the August Philadelphia Fed manufacturing survey will be published on Thursday.
Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Narayana Kocherlakota will speak on Tuesday.
St. Louis Federal Reserve Bank President James Bullard and Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Charles Evans will make public appearances on Thursday.
Charles Rotblut, CFA is a Vice President with AAII and editor of the AAII Journal.
